p: The detection rate of the G1 genotype in the current study is 16% which is in accordance with two previous hospital based studies (11.6% and 14.5%) conducted during the years 2008 and 2014, respectively [ 24, 27]. However, this prevalence rate was lower than a study conducted by Tamim and colleagues who reported that 24.3% of the infection were cause by G1 strains during the year 2010 [ 23]. G1 is responsible for 70% of infections in Europe, North America and Australia, while in south America, Africa and Asia it accounts for 20â€“30% infections [ 70]. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that, Pakistani G1 strains isolated during current study clustered with other strains detected worldwide into two distinct G1 Lineages (Lineage 1 and 2, Fig 3). The different G1 lineages possess antigenic variation at both amino acid and nucleotide level [ 80].
